div.p: Most Reverend Father, what Mr. Martinengo sent to me about the council and the booklet written against you, I immediately sent to you through the same people who delivered it to me; if you have received it, please let us know.
However, you seem to be doing the right thing if you write to Mr. Martinengo yourself and thank him for his diligence.

Now, I have nothing to write; when I advised our councilors about what your councilor is surprised has not yet been written, they replied that they are waiting for a response from Innsbruck and hope the matter can be resolved; if not, they would have certainly written.
There is a village called Samnaun, located at the lower end of the Engadin.
It is about an alp (mountain pasture) and the matter is to be settled justly on both sides.
The law is taken and given according to the agreement; there are 2 judges on our side and 2 on theirs; they take the umpire from ours because they are the plaintiffs.
When the 2 judges along with our appointed umpire appeared on the set day at the designated place, the other 2 from the imperial side did not show up; however, the people came with armed hands.
Our people made themselves ready; meanwhile, the others attacked and took some away.
It is a double offense because they acted willfully in pending legal matters.
If the government in Innsbruck does not show a special seriousness and displeasure about the action, it is a hidden threat.

For these days, Balthasar Planta, the bailiff at Fürstenburg, writes here to the bishop, whose bailiff he is: some large artillery has been taken to Glurns (a small town not far from Fürstenburg) and reinforcements have been sent there; likewise, there are many foreign people lying in Lech and in other places more.

And when it was written to the Fröhlich (thus is the captain at Glurns called) about this, he was told to be without fear; for they are preparing for their new lord Charles, son of Ferdinand; they are waiting for him, etc.
Yet the matter is very suspicious to many, etc.
The case of Glarus troubles me not a little; I see into which arbitrators they have fallen, I understand what they promised before and to what they have repeatedly offered themselves.
They secretly sent a good and faithful man here to us, with whom I discussed many things.
I fear only this, that their discord may result in great harm.

Bäldius is one of those who strictly reject these means; Schuler, Vogel, and others are among those who think of accepting them; the consul of Cham strongly advises this. I wrote my opinion; but this is also the opinion of the councilors.
Please, read the letters first, then seal them and send them with your trusted people; if you think otherwise, I do not oppose you.
I think more about what can be done than what should be done.
Farewell, reverend father, and inform us about French affairs and others, so that I may have something with which to reward the illustrious Mr. Martinengo.
Chur, August 23, 1563.
Your Fabricius.
The councilors and others of ours greet you reverently.
To the most distinguished man Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, his lord and reverend father in Christ.
Zurich.
